metadata.title: Crop Rotation Rules Dataset
metadata.description: A structured collection of 60 agronomic crop rotation rules, each consisting of a rotation principle ('rule') and a corresponding example. These rules are designed to support sustainable farming, improve soil health, manage pests and weeds, and enhance crop yield through effective crop sequencing.

fields.rule: Text description of a crop rotation principle or guideline.
fields.example: An example illustrating how to apply the rule with specific crops or crop sequences.

metadata.format: List of JSON objects with 'rule' and 'example' keys

rules.rule: Non leguminous crops should be followed by leguminous crops and vice/versa.
rules.example: green gram / wheat / maize. If preceding crops are legume or non/legume grown as intercrops or mixed crops, the succeeding crop may be legume or non legume or both.

rules.rule: Restorative crops should be followed by exhaustive or non/restorative crops.
rules.example: seasame / cowpea / green gram / blackgram / groundnut.

rules.rule: Leaf shedding crop should be followed by non/leaf shedding or less exhaustive crops.
rules.example: pulses / cotton / wheat / rice.

rules.rule: Green manuring crop should be followed by grain crops.
rules.example: dhaincha / rice, green gram / cowpea / wheat / maize.

rules.rule: Highly fertilized crops should be followed by non/fertilised crop.
rules.example: maize / black gram / gourds.

rules.rule: Perennial or long duration crops should be followed by seasonal / restorative crops.
rules.example: napier / sugarcane / groundnut / cowpea / green gram.

rules.rule: Fodder crops should be followed by field or vegetable crops.
rules.example: maize + cowpea / wheat / potato / cabbage / onion.

rules.rule: Multicut crops should be succeeded by the seed crops.
rules.example: green gram / maize.

rules.rule: Ratoon crops should be followed by deep rooted restorative crops.
rules.example: sugarcane / jowar / pigeonpea / Lucerne / cowpea.

rules.rule: Fouling crops should be followed by cleaning crops.
rules.example: jowar / maize / potato / groundnut.

rules.rule: Cleaning crops should be followed by nursery crops.
rules.example: potato / colocasia / turmeric / beet / carrot / rice nursery / onion nursery / tobacco nursery / vegetable nursery.

rules.rule: Deep rooted crops should be succeeded by shallow rooted crops.
rules.example: cotton / castor / pigeonpea / potato / lentil / green gram.

rules.rule: Deep tillage crops should be followed by zero or minimal tillage crops.
rules.example: potato / radish / sweet potato / sugarcane / black gram / green gram / green manuring crops.

rules.rule: Dicot crops should be followed by monocot crops.
rules.example: potato / mustard / groundnut / pulses / rice / wheat / sugarcane / jowar. Or dicot + monocot crops should be followed by dicot + monocot or either dicot or monocot crops.

rules.rule: Stiff stubble leaving crops should be followed by minimum intercultivation requiring crops.
rules.example: sugarcane / sorghum / cotton / pigeonpea / fodder crops.

rules.rule: The crops of wet (anaerobic) soil should be followed by the crops of dry (aerobic).
rules.example: rice / Bengal gram / Lathyrus / pulses / oilseeds. Helps reduce difficult/to/control weeds.

rules.rule: The crops susceptible to soil/borne pests and pathogens should be followed by tolerant / break / trap crops.
rules.example: sugarcane / marigold (nematodes), tomato / brinjal / tobacco / potato / rice / pulses (Orobanche), jowar / castor (Striga), berseem / oats (Cuscuta).

rules.rule: The crops with problematic weeds should be followed by cleaning crops, multicut crops, or dissimilar crops.
rules.example: wheat / wet rice (Phalaris minor), berseem / potato / boro rice (Cichorium intybus), mustard / early potato (Cleome viscosa), rice / jute / sugarcane / vegetable / maize + cowpea (Echinochloa crusgalli), jute / multicut fodder / vegetable or Corchorus acutangulus.

rules.rule: Pasture crops should be followed by fodder or seed crop.
rules.example: para grass / maize + cowpea / cowpea / rice bean / tetrakalai.

rules.rule: Silage / hay / cleaning crops should be followed by seed crops.
rules.example: maize / groundnut / onion, cowpea / jowar (for seed crops).

rules.rule: Crops with the same symbiotic / associated microbes should be followed by common host crops.
rules.example: Rhizobium melilote / lucerna, sweet clover, fenugreek; R. trifolli / berseem, Persian clover; R. leguminosorum / peas, lentil, Lathyrus; R. phaseoli / beans, green gram, pillipesara, black gram; R. lupine / Lupines; R. japonicum / cowpea, pigeonpea, guar, sunhemp, Bengal gram, soybean, kudzu.

rules.rule: Follow a legume crop with a high-nitrogen-demanding crop.
rules.example: E.g., follow alfalfa or clover with corn or leafy greens.

rules.rule: Grow less-nitrogen-demanding crops in the second or third year after a legume sod.
rules.example: Root vegetables or grains like oats can follow legumes after year 1.

rules.rule: Grow annual crops for only one year in a particular location.
rules.example: Avoid planting tomatoes or squash in the same bed every year.

rules.rule: Don’t follow one crop with another closely related species.
rules.example: Avoid planting potato after tomato (both are Solanaceae).

rules.rule: Use crop sequences that promote healthier crops.
rules.example: Combine nitrogen-fixers with high-demand feeders in alternating years.

rules.rule: Use crop sequences that aid in controlling weeds.
rules.example: Use cover crops or fast-growing competitive crops between slow growers.

rules.rule: Use longer periods of perennial crops on sloping land.
rules.example: Plant alfalfa or clover for 2-3 years on erosion-prone hills.

rules.rule: Try to grow a deep-rooted crop as part of the rotation.
rules.example: Carrots, sunflowers, or daikon radish can help break compacted soil.

rules.rule: Grow some crops that will leave a significant amount of residue.
rules.example: Corn or sorghum leaves behind organic matter to build soil.

rules.rule: When growing a wide mix of crops, group them into blocks by family, timing, type, nutrient needs, or cultural practices.
rules.example: Plant all Brassicas together early in the season; group legumes with similar watering needs.

rules.rule: Use rotation with cover crops to improve soil and weed/pest management.
rules.example: Plant vetch or rye in off-seasons, roll/crimp them to mulch for the next crop.

rules.rule: In perennial systems, rotate cover crops in alleys between perennial crops.
rules.example: Alternate alleys with different cover crops, switching them each year for biodiversity and frost management.

rules.rule: Avoid planting the same vegetable in the same spot each year.
rules.example: Rotate crops annually to prevent build-up of pests and diseases that overwinter in the soil.

rules.rule: Avoid planting crops from the same family in the same location in consecutive years.
rules.example: Do not follow tomato with eggplant, as both are Solanaceae and share pests/diseases.

rules.rule: Wait 3 to 5 years before replanting the same crop (or family) in the same location.
rules.example: Plant lettuce where you grew tomatoes only after at least 3 years.

rules.rule: Rotate crops by nutrient demand: heavy-feeder → medium-feeder → light-feeder.
rules.example: Year 1: broccoli (heavy), Year 2: carrots (medium), Year 3: beans (light).

rules.rule: Improve soil fertility before growing another heavy feeder.
rules.example: Add compost or grow green manure before restarting the rotation.

rules.rule: Use legumes to boost nitrogen levels in the soil.
rules.example: Plant peas or beans to enrich the soil with nitrogen via rhizobia.

rules.rule: Inoculate legumes in soils where they haven’t been grown before.
rules.example: Use rhizobial inoculants when planting beans in new garden beds.

rules.rule: Use companion plants to attract beneficial insects.
rules.example: Plant dill, fennel, or yarrow to attract parasitic wasps and predatory flies.

rules.rule: Use plants with strong scents to repel pests.
rules.example: Basil, mint, or coriander may confuse or repel pests attacking your main crops.

rules.rule: Use marigolds to reduce nematodes in the soil.
rules.example: Plant densely and till marigolds into the soil after harvest.

rules.rule: Pair crops to make efficient use of space and nutrients.
rules.example: Plant deep-rooted crops with shallow-rooted ones to access different soil layers.

rules.rule: Avoid planting related crops close together.
rules.example: Don't plant broccoli near cabbage—they attract the same pests.

rules.rule: Avoid planting tall crops where they will shade sun-loving crops.
rules.example: Don’t grow corn next to lettuce unless you want partial shade.

rules.rule: Be cautious with allelopathic plants that release root toxins.
rules.example: Sunflower and rye grass can inhibit the growth of nearby sensitive plants.

rules.rule: Avoid planting crops with allelopathic effects before sensitive crops.
rules.example: Avoid planting sorghum before lettuce due to allelopathy (growth inhibition).

rules.rule: Alternate between leaf, fruit, and root crops.
rules.example: Leafy vegetables → fruiting crops → root crops → legumes.

rules.rule: Rotate heavy feeders with soil-resting or low-demand crops.
rules.example: After corn or broccoli, grow turnips or mustard to reduce nutrient drain.

rules.rule: Avoid repeating disease-prone crops in the same bed within 3 years.
rules.example: Don’t plant cucumbers or melons in the same spot where powdery mildew occurred.

rules.rule: Sequence shallow cultivators after deep tillage crops to reduce effort.
rules.example: Grow lentils after potatoes, since the soil will already be loosened.

rules.rule: Use quick-maturing crops to fill seasonal gaps and enhance diversity.
rules.example: Grow radish or baby spinach between two longer crops like tomatoes and beans.

rules.rule: Avoid planting heavy feeders in the same spot in consecutive years to prevent nutrient depletion.
rules.example: Don’t grow corn or tomatoes in the same bed two years in a row. Rotate with legumes like peas or beans.

rules.rule: Follow heavy feeders with nitrogen-fixing or light-feeding crops to restore soil balance.
rules.example: After growing broccoli or eggplant, rotate with peas, Swiss chard, or parsley.

rules.rule: Use medium feeders as transition crops between heavy and light feeders in a rotation cycle.
rules.example: Plant carrots or beets after corn, before moving on to light feeders like radish or turnip.

rules.rule: Include legumes and light-feeders regularly in the rotation to minimize external fertilizer inputs.
rules.example: Grow peas or parsley every few years to replenish nitrogen and reduce soil strain.

rules.rule: Plan your crop rotation cycle using nutrient tiers: heavy → medium → light → nitrogen fixer.
rules.example: Year 1: Corn (heavy), Year 2: Carrot (medium), Year 3: Radish (light), Year 4: Peas (fixer).
